questions.text: An elderly patient has hypercalcemia, elevated serum creatinine, and anaemia. Electrophoresis reveals a monoclonal spike. Her immunofixation test findings are given below. Which of the following best describes her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the investigations, including electrophoresis showing a monoclonal spike and immunofixation revealing increased IgM levels (with a distinct band and no significant band formation above IgG), this patient is diagnosed with multiple myeloma with increased IgM.

Monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance (Option D) is characterised by serum monoclonal protein (M-protein) levels <3 g/dL without end-organ damage, such as hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anaemia, or bone lesions (CRAB features). It is asymptomatic and has a 1% annual risk of progression to multiple myeloma or other plasma cell disorders.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with respiratory distress, and he is diagnosed with pan-acinar emphysema. Which deficiency is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Deficiency of Alpha-1 antitrypsin leads to panacinar emphysema along with liver cirrhosis.

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic condition characterised by low levels or dysfunctional alpha-1 antitrypsin protein.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the alpha-1 antitrypsin gene located on Chromosome 14.
  • Normal individuals have the PiMM genotype, while those with the disease have the PiZZ genotype.
  • This results in significantly reduced levels of functional alpha-1 antitrypsin protein.
  • Carriers possess the PiMZ genotype.
  • The condition primarily affects the lungs, leading to panacinar emphysema and the liver, causing cirrhosis due to abnormal protein accumulation.

The image below shows centriacinar emphysema.

The image below shows paraseptal emphysema.


Type 1 alveolar cells (Option A) are squamous cells responsible for gas exchange in the alveoli. Dysfunction or loss of these cells can impair gas exchange, but does not cause emphysema or structural destruction of alveoli.

Type 2 alveolar cells (Option C) produce surfactant and play a role in alveolar repair. Their dysfunction leads to surfactant deficiency, contributing to conditions like neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, not emphysema.

Albumin (Option D) is a plasma protein involved in maintaining oncotic pressure and the transport of substances. It has no role in the structural integrity of alveoli or the pathogenesis of emphysema.

Learning Objective:

A-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency:

  • Gene on Chromosome 14
    • PiMM: Normal
    • PiZZ: Diseased
    • PiMZ: Carrier
  • Organs affected :
    • Lungs: Pan-acinar emphysema
    • Liver: Cirrhosis

questions.text: A patient presents with hematuria and flank pain. An HPE of a renal mass is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chromophobe RCC has a distinct histological appearance, showing plant cells, perinuclear halos, and raisinoid nuclei similar to the histopathological image above.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases follows the mode of inheritance shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above pedigree shows an X-linked recessive inheritance, which can be seen with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.
  • Males (XY) express the disorder if they inherit the affected X chromosome since they lack a second X for compensation.
  • Females (XX) can be carriers if they inherit one affected X chromosome, often showing no symptoms due to the normal allele on the other X.
  • Affected males cannot pass the disorder to their sons, but can pass the affected X to daughters, making them carriers.

Explanation for other options:

Wilson disease (Option B) is an autosomal recessive disorder involving the ATP7B gene mutation.

Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) (Option C) occurs due to paternal deletion and maternal imprinting of the SNORP gene on chromosome 15q. A subset of PWS can also occur due to maternal disomy.

Achondroplasia (Option D) is an autosomal dominant disorder involving the FGFR3 gene mutation.

questions.text: A child develops skin lesions following exposure to sunlight. Genetic testing reveals a defect in a DNA repair mechanism. Which type of DNA repair is most likely impaired?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical features and the type of genetic defect, this child has Xeroderma pigmentosa, which occurs due to a Nucleotide excision repair defect.


Key Takeaways

questions.text: Diagnose the following based on the images provided below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image reveals cutaneous nodules, and its HPE shows Michaelis-Guttman's bodies; thus, this patient is most likely suffering from Malakoplakia.

Explanation for other options:

Tuberculosis (Option A) granulomas exhibit caseating necrosis surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes and Langhans giant cells, along with acid-fast bacilli on Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

Pyoderma gangrenosum (Option C) is an idiopathic, ulcerative skin condition without granulomas or the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. It primarily involves neutrophilic dermatosis. The clinical appearance is of rapid ulceration with undermined borders.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option D) is a malignant epithelial tumour. It displays keratin pearls, atypical squamous cells, and invasive behaviour but lacks granulomas or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. Cytologic atypia and the absence of granulomatous inflammation differentiate it from malakoplakia.

choices.text: Myxoid degeneration of the bone marrow

questions.text: A patient presents with hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow examination reveals 22% plasma cells, and biopsy shows deposition of pink, acellular material. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features, increased plasma cells, and microscopic findings of pinkish acellular material deposition suggest primary amyloidosis.

Explanation for other options:

Myxoid Degeneration of the Bone Marrow (Option A) refers to the replacement of normal bone marrow tissue with gelatinous material composed of mucopolysaccharides. It is often associated with severe malnutrition, chronic illness, or malignancy.

Plasma Cell Leukaemia (Option C) is a rare and aggressive form of multiple myeloma where plasma cells circulate in large numbers in the blood. It is characterised by anaemia, hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, and organomegaly.

Haemolytic Anaemia (Option D) is a condition where red blood cells are destroyed (haemolysis) faster than they can be produced. It can result from autoimmune disorders, infections, hereditary factors, or external factors like toxins or drugs.

questions.text: An adult male presents with abdominal distension, chronic diarrhoea, visual complaints, and neurological symptoms. Examination of the peripheral blood smear reveals following characteristic findings. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the patient's clinical features and blood smear showing acanthocytes (spur cells), the most likely diagnosis is Abetalipoproteinemia.

Explanation for other options:

Whipple's disease (Option B) occurs due to Tropheryma whipplei (an actinomycete). It is characterised by foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria, which contain periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant granules (partially digested bacteria within lysosomes). While diarrhoea and neurological manifestations are present, protruding abdomen and visual disturbances are less characteristic and peripheral smear findings do not show acanthocytes.

Menetrier's disease (Option C): A rare condition involving hypertrophic gastric folds with protein-losing gastropathy, leading to hypoalbuminemia and oedema. It does not typically cause diarrhoea, visual disturbances, or neurological manifestations, making it unlikely in this case.

Uremia (Option D) results from advanced kidney failure and presents with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, nausea, and confusion. While neurological manifestations may occur, diarrhoea and a protruding abdomen are not typical features. Peripheral smear findings do not align with uremia.

choices.text: The sucrose lysis test is used for confirmation
Flow cytometry is the best investigation
The most common cause of death is heart failure

questions.text: Which of the following statements about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is accurate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Flow cytometry to evaluate CD55 and CD59 is the best investigation to diagnose paroxysmal nocturnal haemoglobinuria.

Sucrose lysis test (Option B) is no longer the test of choice for diagnosis.

questions.text: A male patient with ARDS shows poor response to oxygen therapy. What is the primary role of interleukin-8 (IL-8) in the pathogenesis of ARDS?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Interleukin-8 (IL-8) is a potent chemokine that recruits neutrophils to the site of inflammation in the lungs in Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).

Explanation for other options:

Endothelial Cell Activation (Option A), mediated by IL-1 and TNF-α, leads to increased vascular permeability and upregulation of adhesion molecules. This facilitates leukocyte adhesion and migration, an essential step in the inflammatory response.

Macrophage Activation (Option C) is influenced by IL-4 and IL-10. IL-4 promotes the M2 anti-inflammatory phenotype, supporting tissue repair and resolution of inflammation. IL-10 suppresses pro-inflammatory cytokine production, modulating macrophages to dampen inflammatory responses.

Promotion of Surfactant Production (Option D) is indirectly supported by IL-6 by influencing surfactant protein expression, though it is not the primary cytokine for this role.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with pulmonary haemorrhage and is typically positive for perinuclear ANCA (P-ANCA)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Microscopic polyangiitis is a type of small-vessel vasculitis associated with P-ANCA (perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies).

Explanation for other options:

Monckeberg's sclerosis (Option A) is a form of medial calcific sclerosis where calcium deposits in the walls of medium and small arteries, leading to arterial stiffness. It does not cause inflammation, or pulmonary haemorrhage or doesn't show P-ANCA positivity.

Wegener's granulomatosis (Option C) can cause pulmonary haemorrhage, but it is typically associated with C-ANCA (anti-PR3 antibodies), not P-ANCA.

Polyarteritis nodosa (Option D) involves medium-sized arteries and is not typically associated with pulmonary involvement or P-ANCA positivity. It predominantly affects organs like the kidneys, skin, and gastrointestinal tract, but spares the lungs.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: In iron deficiency anaemia, how is the transferrin saturation affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Transferrin saturation is the serum iron to TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity) ratio and reflects the percentage of transferrin saturated with iron. In iron deficiency, less iron is available for binding to transferrin, leading to a decreased saturation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a typical feature after ileal resection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

After ileal resection, absorption of vitamin B12 is affected, which leads to macrocytic anaemia and not Microcytic hypochromic anaemia, which usually occurs due to iron deficiency or Thalassemia.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent infections, and imaging reveals the absence of the thymus. Further evaluation shows low levels of adenosine deaminase (ADA). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical features and imaging, this child most likely has Severe combined immunodeficiency.

Explanation for other options:

Bruton's Hypogammaglobulinemia (Option A) is an X-linked condition due to a defect in B-cell development, leading to a lack of antibodies (hypogammaglobulinemia). The thymus is typically normal in Bruton's, and ADA levels are not usually affected. The immunodeficiency is primarily due to B-cell dysfunction, not T-cell problems, as seen in SCID.

Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome (Option C) is caused by a genetic defect in MHC class II expression, leading to impaired T-cell function because T cells cannot recognise antigens properly. The thymus is present in Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome, and ADA levels are typically normal, distinguishing it from SCID, which involves thymic absence and low ADA.

DiGeorge Syndrome (Option C) is caused by a deletion on chromosome 22q11.2, leading to thymic hypoplasia and deficient T-cell development. It often presents with a reduced thymus but not its complete absence. ADA levels are normal, and while there is immune dysfunction, the hallmark features (e.g., cardiac defects, facial anomalies) are typically more pronounced in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A tall adult male presents with lens subluxation, disproportionately long limbs, a sunken chest wall, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Which protein is most likely mutated in this individual?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of the patient is highly suggestive of Marfan syndrome, in which there is a mutation of the FBN1 gene leading to defective Fibrillin production.

Explanation for other options:

Collagen (Option B): Defects in collagen lead to conditions like osteogenesis imperfecta, Stickler syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and Alport syndrome.

Elastin (Option C) is predominantly located in ligaments and the walls of blood vessels, especially large arteries like the aorta. The maturation of elastin involves the formation of desmosine cross-links from four lysine residues, contributing to its stability and low turnover rate. Williams-Beuren syndrome is an associated developmental disorder (deletions of the elastin gene) affecting connective tissue and the central nervous system.

Laminin (Option D) is a component of the basement membrane, providing structural support and anchoring the epidermis to the dermis. Mutations in its genes cause epidermolysis bullosa junctionale.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of dyspnea, chest tightness and dry cough. His chest X-ray shows diffuse interstitial fibrosis. He has an occupational history of working in a factory for 20 years. Biopsy examination shows the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the given history and the histopathology image showing dumbbell-shaped asbestos bodies, he is most likely suffering from asbestosis.

Explanation for other options:

Silicosis (Option B) is an occupational disease caused by silica or crystalline quartz exposure.

  • It is seen in people who work in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, and quarrying.
  • Silicosis presents as small, rounded opacities in the upper lobe.
  • Results in calcification of hilar lymph nodes (eggshell calcification)
  • HRCT will show a characteristic crazy paving pattern due to interlobular septal thickening on the background of ground-glass opacity.

Anthracosis/coal workers' pneumoconiosis (Option C) is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners.

  • Alveolar or interstitial macrophages engulf the inhaled carbon pigment, which accumulates in the connective tissue.
  • On prolonged exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis, called complicated coal workers' pneumoconiosis.
  • The upper lobes of the lungs are commonly involved.

Berylliosis (Option D) is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to beryllium.

  • It is seen in people working on processing alloys for high-tech industries like aerospace.
  • Chest radiography shows nodules along the septal lines with hilar and mediastinal lymph node enlargement.
  • HRCT will show pulmonary nodules, diffuse interstitial fibrosis, and interlobular septal thickening.

questions.text: A patient presents with high-grade fever, hepatosplenomegaly, abdominal discomfort, and a white blood cell count exceeding 50,000/mm3. Which genetic abnormality is most likely associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the given clinical features, this patient is most likely suffering from Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML), and the gene abnormality associated with it is t(9;22)

Explanation for other options:

Del (1q) (Option B) is associated with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) and other hematologic disorders but does not typically present with a WBC count > 50,000/mm or the symptoms of fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and abdominal pain.

t(15;17) (Option C) is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL), which presents with coagulopathy, but it usually does not present with such high WBC counts. The primary feature is a higher risk of bleeding, not the symptoms seen here.

Del (3q) deletion (Option D) is associated with certain myeloid malignancies, including MDS and acute myelogenous leukaemia (AML), but it does not commonly present with such a dramatically elevated WBC count or hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: Identify the syndrome associated with the chromosomal pattern shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a pair of chromosomes with a paternal region deletion associated with Prader-Willi syndrome.

Explanation for other options:

Angelman Syndrome (Option A) occurs due to microdeletion or mutation of the maternal chromosome 15 (or paternal chromosome 15 imprinting).

Clinical Features:

  • Severe intellectual disability
  • Ataxia
  • Seizures
  • Characteristic "happy demeanour" with frequent laughter.
  • Obesity and hyperphagia are not typical features.

Rett Syndrome (Option C) occurs due to a mutation in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome, primarily affecting females.

Clinical Features:

  • Normal development initially, followed by regression with loss of motor and cognitive skills.
  • Stereotypic hand movements,
  • Severe intellectual disability.

Cri du Chat Syndrome (Option D) occurs due to deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5 (5p deletion).

Clinical Features:

  • High-pitched
  • A cat-like cry in infancy
  • Microcephaly
  • Intellectual disability and distinct facial features.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies are associated with celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Celiac disease is associated with anti-tTG (Anti-tissue transglutaminase).

Explanation for other options:

ANCA (Anti-Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies) (Option B) is associated with vasculitides, such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (C-ANCA) and Microscopic Polyangiitis (P-ANCA). They have no role in the diagnosis of celiac disease.

ASCA (Anti-Saccharomyces Cerevisiae Antibodies) (Option C) is commonly associated with Crohn's disease, a type of inflammatory bowel disease. They are not linked to celiac disease, which involves immune-mediated small bowel damage due to gluten.

AMA (Anti-Mitochondrial Antibodies) (Option D) is a hallmark of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), a chronic liver disease affecting the bile ducts. They have no relevance to celiac disease.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with anemia, a platelet count of 25,000/mm3, and prolonged prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time. A peripheral blood smear image is provided. Which fusion gene is most likely involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the above histology, which shows faggot cells containing Auer rods, which is a feature of Acute myeloid leukaemia (M3), the fusion gene PML-RARA is formed due to t(15:17).

Explanation for other options:

RUNX1-RUNX1T1 (Option B) is found in AML with t(8;21). It typically presents with anaemia and neutropenia, but platelet levels are normal or slightly low. Coagulopathy is uncommon.

INV(16) (Option C) is associated with AML with abnormal eosinophils. Coagulopathy is rare, and severe thrombocytopenia is not typical.

IGH-NSD2 (Option D) is seen in multiple myeloma with t(4;14). Features include bone pain and renal dysfunction, not coagulopathy or low platelets.

questions.text: What is the gene commonly involved in carcinoma histology shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology shown in the image shows Orphan Annie's eye nucleus (seen in papillary thyroid cancer) associated with the BRAF V600 gene.

Papillary thyroid cancer is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterised by lymphatic spread.

  • It often presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy.
  • Associated with BRAF mutations and RET-PTC fusion.
  • It has the best prognosis among thyroid malignancies.
  • HPE shows
    • True papillae: Fingerlike projections with fibrovascular cores.
    • Orphan Annie eye nuclei: Optically clear nucleus produced due to artefact.
    • Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI).
    • Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus.
    • Presence of psammoma bodies - Dystrophic calcifications.

Explanation for other options:

RAS (Option A) mutations are commonly found in

  • Follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Follicular adenomas.
  • Colorectal cancer
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Lung adenocarcinoma.

RET (Option B) mutation is seen in

  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (as part of MEN2 syndromes)
  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma (via RET/PTC rearrangements)

P53 (Option D) mutation is seen in Breast, lung, and colon carcinomas.

Learning Objective:

BRAF V600E mutation seen in:

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Papillary carcinoma thyroid
  • Juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma
  • Colon cancer
  • Melanoma

questions.text: TTF-1 immunohistochemical marker is associated with which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

TFF-1 (Trefoil Factor 1) is an immunohistochemical marker for lung adenocarcinoma

Markers that are useful in lung adenocarcinomas are:

  • TTF-1
  • MUC1
  • Napsin A

Explanation for other options:

P40 and p63 are the Markers for squamous cell carcinoma (Option A)

Chromogranin is a marker for Small-cell lung cancer (Option C). It is a protein found in the secretory vesicles of neuroendocrine cells and is most commonly used as a marker for neuroendocrine tumours such as small-cell lung cancer, carcinoid tumours, and neuroblastomas.

Cytokeratins (CK7 and CK18) and Ki-67 are the markers for Large cell carcinoma (Option D)

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic smoker presents with an oral lesion, as shown in the image below. Which is the stain used to identify this pathology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Toluidine blue is the most appropriate supravital stain for identifying oral or vocal cord lesions in smokers.

  • It is particularly useful in detecting early changes or abnormalities in cells before they undergo irreversible damage or cell death.
  • It is a valuable tool for identifying dysplasia, precancerous lesions, and early-stage cancer.

Explanation for other options:

Congo Red (Option B) is primarily used to identify amyloid deposits under polarised light. It is not useful for detecting dysplasia or squamous cell carcinoma in oral lesions or vocal cords.

Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) (Option C) are commonly used for routine histopathology to examine tissue structure. H&E is used to assess the overall architecture of tissue, such as looking for signs of malignancy or dysplasia.

Oil Red O (Option D) is used to stain lipids in tissues and is commonly used to identify cell fat content, such as in lipid-rich lesions or tissue samples.

Reference:

Histological Stains: A Literature Review and Case Study - PMC

choices.text: Type 2 Von Willebrand disease is associated with a moderate bleeding tendency.
Type 3 Von Willebrand disease is associated with a complete absence of the Von Willebrand factor.
Type 1 Von Willebrand disease presents with severe bleeding since childhood.
Type 2 Von Willebrand disease includes subtypes with varying defects in the von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding Von Willebrand's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type 1 Von Willebrand disease presents with mild bleeding as there is only a mild deficiency of vWF.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female with a height of 4 feet has a karyotype, as shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the given karyotyping, there is a monosomy of the X chromosome, which is seen in Turner syndrome.

Explanation for other options:

Klinefelter syndrome (Option B) is male hypogonadism resulting from two or more X chromosomes and one or more Y chromosomes. It is characterised by hypogonadism in males, gynecomastia, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, frontal baldness, narrow shoulders, wide hips and long legs.

Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome (MRKHS) (Option C) is characterised by failure of development of the uterus and the vagina, while ovarian function and external genitalia are normal.

Edwards syndrome (Option D) is caused by the presence of Trisomy 18. It is characterised by low birth weight, closed fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, microcephaly, micrognathia, cardiac and renal malformations, and intellectual disability. 95% of cases die in the 1st year of life.

questions.text: A child presents with failure to pass stools and is diagnosed with Hirschsprung disease. Which of the following colon layers will show a congenital absence of neurons?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Hirschsprung's disease, the congenital absence of neurons is seen in the submucosa (Meissner's plexus) and the muscularis propria (myenteric plexus). This occurs due to a mutation in the RET gene, which leads to the loss of Ganglion cells.

questions.text: Following gastrectomy procedure which vitamin is to be supplemented for the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can occur following gastrectomy due to intrinsic factor deficiency; thus, Vitamin B12 supplementation is done following gastrectomy.

Factors Affecting Vitamin B12 Absorption:

  1. Intrinsic Factor
    • A glycoprotein secreted by the gastric mucosa parietal cells.
    • It binds selectively to active forms of vitamin B12, which is essential for its absorption.
    • Deficiency occurs in patients who have undergone gastrectomy.
  2. Gastric Acidity and Enzymes: Adequate gastric acid and pepsin release vitamin B12 from its protein-bound form in food, making it available for cyclophilin.
  3. Cobalophilin:
    • A binding protein in saliva that initially binds vitamin B12 in the duodenum.
    • It is hydrolysed to release vitamin B12 for intrinsic factor binding.
  4. Pancreatic Sufficiency:
    • The pancreas aids digestion and absorption, possibly through cobalophilin hydrolysis.
  5. Ileal Receptors: Specialised receptors in the distal ileum recognise and bind the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 complex for absorption.

Explanation for other options:

Vitamin A (Option A) is primarily absorbed in the small intestine, not the stomach, and its absorption is usually unaffected by gastrectomy. Deficiency is more commonly associated with fat malabsorption (e.g., biliary disease or pancreatic insufficiency) rather than loss of gastric function.

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) (Option B) deficiency is associated with chronic alcoholism, malnutrition, or prolonged vomiting (e.g., hyperemesis gravidarum). Although gastrectomy may reduce dietary intake, thiamine absorption occurs in the small intestine, so deficiency is less likely unless there is concurrent malnutrition.

Vitamin C (Option C) absorption occurs in the small intestine, and its deficiency is rare in gastrectomy patients unless there is severe dietary insufficiency. It is not directly affected by gastric acid or intrinsic factors.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with a cerebellar mass and a renal tumour, along with a similar family history. Which of the following is responsible for his findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

VHL is associated with both clear cell Renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

  • Autosomal dominant disorder of VHL gene on chromosome 3p.

It is associated with

  • Cerebellar Hemangioblastomas: Highly vascular tumours in the central nervous system, especially the cerebellum.
  • Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC): Often clear cell type, multifocal and bilateral
  • Retinal hemangioblastomas, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic cysts.

Explanation for other options:

NF (Neurofibromatosis) (Option B)

  • Type 1 (NF1): Characterized by cutaneous neurofibromas, cafe-au-lait spots, and optic gliomas.
  • Type 2 (NF2): Associated with bilateral vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and spinal tumours.
  • Neurofibromatosis does not involve renal tumours or cerebellar hemangioblastomas.

TSC (Tuberous Sclerosis Complex) (Option C) is caused by mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes. It is associated with Angiofibromas, cortical tubers, subependymal giant cell astrocytomas, and renal angiomyolipomas.

Li-Fraumeni Syndrome is caused by a mutation in the TP53 gene (Option D): It is associated with multiple sarcomas, breast cancer, leukaemia, and brain tumours.

Reference:

Von Hippel-Lindau Syndrome | Treatment & Management | Point of Care

questions.text: A 27-year-old football player is brought to the ER after he collapsed due to sudden cardiac arrest. Based on the biopsy findings of his cardiac tissue, what is the most likely cause of his death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows a helter-skelter appearance, which is a characteristic feature of Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM):

  • Etiology:
    • Mutations in any one of several genes that encode sarcomeric proteins.
    • Most are missense mutations.
    • Most commonly in the genes encoding
      • Myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C)
      • β-myosin heavy chain (β-MHC/MYH7)
      • Cardiac TnI, TnT, and α-tropomyosin
  • Characterised by
    • Myocardial hypertrophy
    • Poorly compliant left ventricular myocardium
    • Abnormal diastolic filling
    • Intermittent ventricular outflow obstruction.
  • It is the leading cause of left ventricular hypertrophy unexplained by other clinical or pathologic causes.
  • It is a leading cause of sudden death in the young.

Explanation for other options:

Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option B) is characterised by left ventricular dilation and impaired systolic function. Histopathologically, it shows "ninja star nuclei", where cardiomyocyte nuclei are abnormally arranged in a star-shaped or irregular pattern due to fibre stretching. DCM also presents with cardiomyocyte hypertrophy, interstitial fibrosis, and myocardial fibre degeneration.

Restrictive cardiomyopathy (Option C) shows signs of fibrotic changes in the myocardium.

Arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy (Option D) shows infiltration of fat in the right ventricular myocytes.

questions.text: A child presents with pruritic skin lesions and chronic diarrhoea. A gluten-free diet is recommended. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the patient's symptoms and the advice that was given, the child is most likely suffering from celiac disease, which is a sensitivity to Gluten.

Explanation for other options:

Whipple's disease (Option B) is a rare systemic infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei.

It presents with chronic didiarrhoeaamalabsorption, weight loss, and arthralgia. Skin lesions are not characteristic.

Crohn's disease (Option C) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting any part of the gastrointestinal tract. It often presents with abdominal pain, diarrhoea (often non-bloody), weight loss, and perianal disease. Skin manifestations like erythema nodosum and pyoderma gangrenosum may occur, but are not itchy.

Ulcerative colitis (Option D) is a chronic inflammatory condition limited to the colon and rectum. It presents with bloody diarrhoea, tenesmus, and abdominal pain. No itchy skin lesions are associated with ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: Identify the disease associated with the following image provided
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows a 'crumpled tissue paper' appearance, a characteristic finding of Gaucher's disease.

Gaucher disease:

  • It is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by mutations in the GBA gene, which encodes the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.
  • Accumulation of glucocerebroside (glucosylceramide) within lysosomes of macrophages, forming characteristic Gaucher cells.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Hematologic: Pancytopenia
    • Skeletal: Bone crisis, severe bone pain.
    • Neurological: Parkinsonism, cognitive impairment, neuropathy
  • Investigations:
    • Bone marrow examination: Shows Gaucher cells with a characteristic wrinkled tissue paper appearance. Gaucher cells are macrophages that accumulate with glucocerebroside.
    • Enzyme assay: Demonstrates reduced activity of glucocerebrosidase in leukocytes or fibroblasts.
    • Long bone X-rays may show the Erlenmeyer flask deformity.

Explanation for other options:

Tay-Sachs disease (Option B) is caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A, leading to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides in neurons. It presents with progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, cherry-red spot on the macula, but no Gaucher cells in the bone marrow.

Sandhoff's disease (Option C) occurs due to a hexosaminidase A and B deficiency, leading to GM2 ganglioside accumulation. It presents with similar neurodegenerative symptoms as Tay-Sachs but with visceral involvement, unlike Gaucher's disease.

Fabry's disease (Option D) is caused by a deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A, leading to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. It presents with neuropathic pain, angiokeratomas, corneal opacities, and renal/cardiac complications. No Gaucher cells are observed.
